p: Within the past decade, a new genotype of RSV-A identified in Ontario, Canada (ON1) has emerged ( Eshaghi et al., 2012). This genotype is characterized by a 72-nucleotide duplication in the HVR2. ON1 has since been detected in Europe, Africa, Asia, and the Americas ( Cui et al., 2013; Valley-Omar et al., 2013; Pierangeli et al., 2014). Meanwhile, an RSV-B genotype identified in Buenos Aires, Argentina (BA) similarly contained a 60-nucleotide duplication in the HVR2 ( Trento et al., 2003). BA has subsequently became so prevalent globally that it largely replaced other RSV-B genotypes ( Trento et al., 2010). Gene insertion seen in both RSV-A and RSV-B HVR2 may have affected the antigenicity of the G protein and enabled viral escape from the host immunity, thus mediating their predominance in recent years.
